et: combining form from Greek {it}sark-, sárx{/it} "flesh, piece of meat," probably going back to Indo-European {it}*tu̯r̥ḱ-,{/it} noun derivative of a verbal base {it}*tu̯erḱ-{/it} "cut, shape by cutting, carve" whence, also with zero grade, Avestan{it} θβərəsaiti{/it} "(s/he) carves, shapes," {it}θβōrəštar-{/it} "shaper, creator," Sanskrit {it}Tvaṣṭar-,{/it} name of a creator deity, and perhaps, from {it}*tu̯orkos{/it} or {it}*turkos,{/it} Old Irish {it}torc{/it} "wild boar," Welsh {it}twrch,{/it} Middle Breton {it}tourch{/it}
